comments.commentBody: Ashton Kutcher plays idiots and fools but is not one, and is probably rather unhappy to be quoted by the likes of Cruz.

Senator Ted Cruz quotes Ashton Kutcher, most famous for a movie called, "Dude, Where Did I Park My Car?" The Republicans are no longer the party of Lincoln. When they are reduced to drawing their quotes from Twitter celebrities instead of from the great minds, I believe they don't even remember who Lincoln was.

One extra thought on gerrymandering. Here in California we passed a very interesting proposition a couple of years ago. Not only is districting done by a neutral commission, but general elections take the top 2 vote getters from the primary (rather than always one Democrat and one Republican).

So e.g. in a conservative district if two Republicans both get more primary votes than any Democrat, the two Republicans face each other in the general election. This gives the more moderate Republican the chance to win, where he wouldn't have a chance in the primary, and a Democrat wouldn't have a chance in the general election. It at least theoretically pushes both parties toward the center.

We certainly don't do everything right here in California, but occasionally we hit on something very good, and I'm beginning to think that this is one of them.

I respectfully respond to David E's comments of 9/25 concerning "Planned Communities" in America. It would seem our differences lie within the definition of "planned" more so than with historic validity. For the 3000 acre "Tuxedo Park" NY, the founder c.1886 created a 300 acre reservoir, a piped and pumped fresh water system, a basic sewer system, 26 miles of improved roads, a Gate House, a Country Club, an equestrian facility, a Police Department and a Rail/Vessel connection with Manhattan; all before any homes were constructed. If there existed similarly "planned", private communities elsewhere in America as early as 1820, I would love to learn of them and visit.

Regards,
Barbara R.
I'll take the "Over" on that release date.  Gran Tourismo 5 was delayed several times.

My experience with my 2012 Prius is that I average a solid 43 mpg in all sorts of driving--lower in the winter, higher in the summer--despite my heavy foot. Granted that is less than the EPA combined average of 50 mpg but not bad nevertheless. If I do try to maximize my mileage by driving carefully I can easily top 60 mpg in the city and 50 on the highway.

Well sounds like they are on the right track.
As when I bought one of my first hybrids,the 2005 Honda Accord.

And the only way to get their sticker mpg of 37 mpg, is if I drive like a a little old lady, under 55 mph and keep it under 1500 rpm.

Or, if I can buy pure unleaded gas, the non the water based ethanol blank, or get a good tail wind it can be done. ^^^^^

Average still, is a good city & highway, is 32 mpg after almost 9 years & counting come December 04.
Jesus was a Socialist as well- except that he encouraged people to pay their taxes.

@mancuroc: Not only was Ayn Rand an athiest, but she was a *fervent* supporter of abortion. But nobody explained that to the Paul Ryans, the Rand Pauls or the Ted Cruzes of the world any more than anybody ever explained the theme to "Green Eggs and Ham" to the Princeton and Harvard "educated" Cruz.

Ayn Rand was also more than happy to become a "taker" by accepting her Social Security payments when the time came.  And every time I see this guy Cruz all I can see is Tailgunner Joe - I'm old enough to remember seeing him on t.v. and it's not any better the second time around!

"Reading of “Green Eggs and Ham” by Dr. Seuss"

The story made exactly the opposite point from what Cruz intended. Besides, wait until he finds out that Dr Seuss was a socialist - maybe he'll disown him he way Paul Ryan disowned Ayn Rand when they told him she was an atheist.
.
You don't think that such strategizing goes on in the private sector?
Who elects the politicians?  "We the people" have no responsibility?

How will the military's budget be helped by government shut down?  Under current congressional rules (Hastert in the house, filibuster in the senate), the power to say "no," to halt movement, is vested in the representatives of a small minority of citizens.  But the power to say "yes" still requires a majority, at least of those representatives.

Your post is self serving wishful thinking. An "equal raising of intelligence"? Who said that? Who said if you removed the stress of poverty "all members of this group would perform exceptionally"? You turned the article upside -down.

The article claims that the stress of poverty affects decision-making by reducing long term thinking which creates a vicious cycle. Their modest suggestion is to design anti-poverty services to be less subject to short term thinking (as opposed to loan-sharking which takes advantage of the tendency to short term thinking).

If you believe it's easy "to reduce a person of I.Q. 130 to no real expression of intelligence" why can't you imagine that reducing stress on millions would enable persons of I.Q. above imbecility to act more intelligently? That would be a huge benefit to society.

What would actually reduce poverty is higher wages. What enables employers to enjoy the profits from paying low wages is the idea the poor are poor because "the type of seed matters". In other words pay as little as possible because those who take the job don't deserve any better. Thinking along those lines is so third-world.

That's why the Clinton administration should never have entered into this MFN trade agreement with no protection against currency manipulation, intellectual property theft, state subsidies, etc.  It was a bad deal which cost us greatly.  And, Clinton, Rubin, Summers joined the laissez faire Harding, Coolidge, Hoover and Mellon crowd eviscerating the FDR New Deal safety and sound financial system.  We haven't  been well governed for decades.
Leapy, I have bad news for you.  It only matters if I know what I'm looking something.

OLaszlo, I do like the part about the SIAMESE CAT HIGHERED to act as a surveillance CAMERA, and her admonishment to Little Richard (related to Stuart Little?). That might be what our young Baxter is aspiring to, when he scales the window screens to the top, hangs there like a limpet.

You tell a fine EPEE's ODIC TAIL.

Did someone ask for some Little Richard?

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QFq5O2kabQo

Quite a SHIPSHAPE puzzle from our dynamic duo today, a victory really, peppered with a little Will here and there, I am sure. It is rare to see twelve theme entries in a 15x15, even if they are all only four letters long each (except the two fives). But the main reason IRATE this puzzle very highly is that there is nothing tabooed or recooked in it.

Deb, thanks for your anecdote, it was more fun than a two-room-mountain-cabinful of bouncing boys.

I love the SIAMESE CAT ruling over the square room full of letters and blocks, like so many toys, surveilling her domain from a perch atop the door ajar, her cheek LEANING ON a TENON protruding from its corner. She seems to be saying: "I AM A CAMERA."

On closer inspection, she is actually DOZEN' off listening to a ticking CLOCK and the TENOR sax wailing softly from the CD player beneath one of the LAMPS in the room, until the GALOP of a mouse in the FOUR-PART corner wakes her up.

Ostensibly, she was HIGHERED to keep rodents in check, but she's a lazy kitty with a live-and-let-live philosophy. She is never IRATE, avoids RIOTS, and never LEAPT on that little house mouse called Richard. Now she opens one eye and with a yawn says to him: "ODIC, would you keep quiet down there? I want to GO TO SLEEP."

Which is what I have to do right now. Good night.

Forgot to add:

Despite a sprinkling of orange marmalade cats, all our family felines have been relaxed and raunchy SIAMESE CATS (chocolates, blues; seals and lilac points...all recent ones being rescues). So that entry pleased me a lot.

However, I read the clue too quickly, and first thought it asked for a 'blue-eyed poet'. That put me in mind of the closing line of an e.e. cummings poem about Dylan Thomas, that has stuck with me for many years.

"so what i want to know is,
how do you like your blue-eyed boy, mister death"

I had read that poem not long after a blue-eyed boy I knew had died, possibly by suicide.

MTF, you misread me -- that was an admiring comment!

To reiterate: wow!

Yes, I've written often that they should fire Cashman. Good for you, Gordon. If they want testimony, have them talk with Raul Ibanez, Russell Martin and Nick Swisher for starters, then throw in Joba and Hughes to top it off.
But more important, they need to realize that they can't win by being cheapskates and letting everyone else pick up the available talent - Jake Peavy is a good example. And Victorini. I wrote in April that they were working so hard to avoid paying the "luxury tax" that they forgot that the real payoff will be an empty Stadium because the team is no longer worth watching. How's that money-saving working out for you, Hank? And furthermore, Cano would be a fool to re-sign with a team without a prayer of being in contention during the tenure of his next contract. This disaster of a season was a self-made destruction. George is spinning in his grave.

I'm no Cashman fan, but how is this his "fault"?

I'm LESS of a fan of the (these) Steinbrenners.
If "frugality" is more important than winning to them then this is the result... no one can be shocked.
Fire Hal and Hank!!! I am not a big Cash's admirer, but let's be fair:   the Stinkbrenner brothers tied his hands.

Hank and Hal To Do List:

1) Fire Cashman
2) Fire Cashman
etc.

http://espn.go.com/mlb/player/_/id/3115/alex-rodriguez
And almost surely the most expensive.

Sharon,

Just a reminder that as education for women and girls improves (worldwide), as opportunities in the workplace for women grow, as quality of life increases, and as the economic burden of children (childcare, college) increases, women limit family size. In fact, fertility rates are falling worldwide, including the developing world.

I went to an interesting talk once with Lynn Margulis - a microbiologist whose greatest contribution was recognizing the symbiotic nature of mitochondria with the eukaryotic cell, but who also worked with James Lovelock on the Gaia Hypothesis. The Gaia Hypothesis is simply that life on earth creates the unique conditions necessary for life to be self-sustaining (for example, our oxygen-containing atmosphere). One of the things she said at that lecture that will always stick with me is that the idea of "saving the Earth" is essentially a Christian one, and one that she finds incredibly arrogant.

In the thinking that I have done since then, and watching some Earth Firsters demonstrate in a small Idaho town with a chant of "Earth First! People Last!" in 1993 and also seeing the profound depression that hits environmentalists in their mid-20s, and seeing the apathy on the faces of my 12-year old science students who have heard all too often, "Humans are the worst thing that ever happened," I can't help but think that the environmental movement is misanthropic and apocalyptic, and probably scientifically misguided.

Len,

I am sorry if reality is intruding upon your cognitive toolkit.

I think your projections are interesting, I would expect flat +/- till 2030, perhaps cooling with a look back trend line starting at or near 1995, 45 +/- years of no warming and possible cooling.

2030 to 2060 is more interesting of course. On balance a warming regime should then set in (unless the sun really stays quiet), in which case more flat-line or cooling.

In any case, while you may dislike that nature has quashed the models, predictions, projection, the IPCC, the climategaters, et al, it has done so, further, according to Ben Santer, famed warmist and pugilist, 17 years represents a trend, not noise, as to the troposphere, we are on the cusp of 17 years now.

I am not sure where 'blah blah blah' ... fits into any of this, but a rough translation might be, 'I want to ignore what is real in favor of my, and others, projection'.

That my friend, is not science.
I realized the magnitude of the problem when I was watching this year's old timers game and couldn't distinguish between the retirees and the active roster.
Obama has blinked so many times before.  Why do you think this time will be different?  Just asking.

The encouraging development here is that Obama has refused to negotiate with the Republicans, and I suspect that he will do the same when raising the debt ceiling comes before Congress. Don't negotiate with terrorists.
Absolutely. It's even more polarizing in Seattle, with very rich individuals changing the nature of entire neighborhoods (South Lake Union, for example).

Sounds like the description of the backgrounds and families of the kids you are describing as victims would be the same description of the backgrounds and families of the grown ups who initiate the trafficking.

Great rant. Unfortunately, many of us remember Reza (God's shadow on the Earth) Shah as high on Amnesty International's list of worst dictators. The dynasty was put in place by the West.
Iran had a very major fight with Iraq (the latter, using a wide range of banned weapons, egged on by the West.) I'm not so sure that it is "spoiling" for further warfare. The bellicose rhetoric plays well with the rural population, of course.
There is no evidence that, other than a tiny percentage of zealots, the Iranian people want a return of the Peacocks. What they need is the mullahs off their shoulders.

Mike;
Excellent comments!!! Iranian folks do hate mullahs and time of this tyrannical repressive regime is being counted. 26 years of Shah's despotic rule (dreadful Savak) followed by 34 years of clerics/ revolutionary guards
(Besieges thugs); Iranians had enough of BOTH. They need CHANGE!!!!

The Iranian clerical regime has been spoiling for a fight since the overthrow of the Shah in 1979, Allah praise his memory and his son who will one day rule.  The regime and its components, including the radicals like the army, the Revolutionary Guards and the Quds force had better agree on a unified position soon.  They are losing Syria to Al Qaeda, Hezbollah is despised as traitors in the Sunni world and Iran is more and more isolated.  If they want a war, which is against the interests of the USA and Iran, we can give them one and reinstate the son of the Shah, much as Kermit Roosevelt overthrew Mossadegh.  Read his book, Countercoup, as a dress rehearsal if Iran and the Shia won't come to terms.
